[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] The rhythmic clang of the telegraph keys, each tap a tiny hammer blow against the silence of the vast, empty plains, brings Susannah a strange peace. It's a comfort born of control, of knowing that she's the conduit between worlds, connecting distant voices and weaving together a tapestry of information. But this comfort comes at a cost; the constant barrage of messages, whispers of greed, violence, and desperation, slowly chips away at her soul, leaving her with a growing sense of unease.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Josephine Blackwood's men, they are wolves, teeth bared and eyes gleaming with the thrill of the hunt. They enforce her will, their loyalty bought and paid for with blood money. Towns burned, lives snuffed out, all in the name of progress.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah's unwavering belief in her own cunning, her ability to manipulate and deceive, is what truly makes her strong, even if she doesn't realize it. She mistakes this talent for cold, calculated control as strength, but it blinds her to the genuine connections and vulnerabilities that could offer her true support and solace.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah arrived in Copper Canyon with nothing but a worn satchel and a head full of carefully crafted lies. She'd heard whispers of the Prairie Firebird Railway's expansion, of the opportunities it offered for those willing to take risks. Josephine Blackwood, the company's iron-fisted head, was known for her ruthlessness, but also for her willingness to reward those who proved their loyalty. Seeing a chance to climb the ranks and secure a life of comfort and power, Susannah presented herself as a skilled telegraph operator, her fabricated credentials as convincing as her steely gaze. Blackwood, ever shrewd, saw something in Susannah—a flicker of ambition that mirrored her own—and took her on.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah views Josephine Blackwood with a mixture of admiration and fear. She recognizes Blackwood's cunning and ruthless efficiency, traits she both envies and secretly despises. While Susannah uses her deceit for personal gain, she sees Blackwood's ambition as something larger, a force that shapes the very landscape around them. There's a grudging respect there, but also a deep-seated fear of being caught in the crosshairs of Blackwood's ambition.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah doesn't enjoy her job in the traditional sense; the endless clatter of the telegraph keys and the weight of secrets she carries offer little in the way of genuine satisfaction. She works for Prairie Firebird Railway because it provides the means to an end—a comfortable life, a facade of respectability, and the power that comes with manipulating those around her. The railway is merely a tool, a means to an end in her elaborate game of deception.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah believes Josephine Blackwood cares about people like her only insofar as they serve her purposes. She remembers a time when a group of workers were injured in a construction accident. Blackwood, while publicly expressing concern, ultimately prioritized getting the railway back on schedule over ensuring the workers received proper medical attention. This incident, along with Blackwood's ruthless treatment of those who dare to question her authority, has convinced Susannah that loyalty and compassion are mere tools in Blackwood's arsenal, to be wielded when expedient and discarded when no longer useful.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah views the labor movement with a mixture of disdain and apprehension. She sees it as a threat to the established order, a messy and unpredictable force that could disrupt the delicate balance of power she has carefully constructed. Lucinda Mayfield, with her fiery speeches and unwavering belief in the rights of the workers, represents everything Susannah fears—a challenge to her carefully crafted control, a reminder of the vulnerability she hides beneath her mask of deception.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah believes Lucinda Mayfield genuinely cares about the plight of people like her, those caught in the gears of the railway's relentless expansion. She recalls a time when Mayfield intervened on behalf of a group of workers who were being cheated out of their wages. While Susannah herself profited from the situation, she couldn't help but be impressed by Mayfield's unwavering commitment to justice, even in the face of threats from Blackwood and her enforcers.

[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Josephine Blackwood heard the reports of poor conditions experienced by railroad construction workers but attitude is that such things are the price of progress, the cost of carving civilization out of this unforgiving land. believes that every life lost is a tally mark on the ledger, a sacrifice on the altar of ambition. What is the price of a man's life when weighed against the riches that await? Every penny pinched, every corner cut, adds another dollar to the war chest. Let the fools cry about safety and comfort, in the end, their suffering will be forgotten, their bones buried beneath the rail ties that bind this nation together.

[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] In the coal mines, Lucinda Mayfield had witnessed the power of strikes and the formation of early labor unions. Though initially skeptical, she saw how collective action could lead to improved conditions and a sense of solidarity among the workers.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Lucinda Mayfield's upbringing instilled in her a strong sense of fairness and justice. she witnessed the harsh treatment of the railroad workers and recognized the parallels to her own experiences in the mines.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Lucinda Mayfield draws inspiration from figures like William H. Sylvis, the founder of the National Labor Union, and the writings of Henry George, who proposed radical land reforms to address economic inequality and most recently published an article titled 'What the Railroad Will Bring Us' in October of 1868.

[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Lucinda Mayfield was born in a coal mining town in Pennsylvania and learned the value of hard work and perseverance at a young age. she witnessed firsthand the exploitation of workers by the coal barons, sparking a quiet anger within her.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Susannah Blackburn just arrived at the saloon after a hard day of work.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Susannah Blackburn overheard at the saloon: Lucinda Mayfield -- "...enough is enough! We won't be silenced, we won't be ignored. It's time to walk out!"
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Millicent Cartwright overheard at the saloon: Lucinda Mayfield -- "...enough is enough! We won't be silenced, we won't be ignored. It's time to walk out!"
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Silas Redburn just arrived at the saloon after a hard day of work.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Millicent Cartwright just arrived at the saloon after a hard day of work.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [scene type] evening_0
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Silas Redburn won a few dollars playing cards against a weathered rancher.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] However, Silas Redburn did not gain any coin because because the rancher was actually a con artist who tricked Silas into thinking he had won.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] As Susannah Blackburn sipped her whiskey and munched on peanuts, she overheard snippets of conversations revealing that Lucinda Mayfield was planning a strike and that many workers were eager to join her.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Silas Redburn overheard at the saloon: Lucinda Mayfield -- "...enough is enough! We won't be silenced, we won't be ignored. It's time to walk out!"
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [effect on Josephine Blackwood] It does not directly affect her status, but it could indirectly affect her plans for the evening if Silas Redburn, now flush with cash, decides to stay at the saloon longer than anticipated.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:10] Summary of a conversation between Millicent Cartwright, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield. Lucinda defends her decision to call for a strike, arguing that it is necessary to fight for fair treatment despite the potential consequences.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:10] Millicent Cartwright listened intently to Lucinda and Josephine's conversation, carefully weighing the arguments for and against the strike while considering its potential impact on her family. As a result, she began to feel a growing sense of unease about the situation.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:20] Summary of a conversation between Millicent Cartwright, Silas Redburn, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield. The women are discussing the possibility of a strike, with Lucinda advocating for it while others express concerns about the risks involved.
[03 Oct 1868 09:00:00] It is morning, Millicent Cartwright must decide how to spend the day.
[03 Oct 1868 09:00:00] It is morning, Silas Redburn must decide how to spend the day.
[03 Oct 1868 09:00:00] It is morning, Susannah Blackburn must decide how to spend the day.

[03 Oct 1868 09:00:00] go to work
[03 Oct 1868 10:00:00] It is morning, Josephine Blackwood must decide whether to cave to pressure and raise wages or hold firm and deny the workers their demands.
[03 Oct 1868 10:00:00] [scene type] boss_morning
[03 Oct 1868 10:00:00] Boss Josephine Blackwood holds firm and leaves wages unchanged at 1.25 coin per day.
[03 Oct 1868 10:00:00] [set wage] 1.25
[03 Oct 1868 10:00:00] Leave wages unchanged

[03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [scene type] evening_1
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Susannah Blackburn ordered a glass of beer and listened to the other patrons' conversations, overhearing Lucinda Mayfield discussing the strike's demands for better pay and working conditions.
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] Summary of a conversation between Millicent Cartwright, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield. The women are discussing the potential benefits and costs of the strike, with some advocating for better working conditions while others express concerns about financial implications.
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] Millicent Cartwright carefully considered Lucinda's response and asked, "Lucinda, you mentioned the well-being of the workers. What do you mean by that?" causing Josephine Blackwood to become irritated and excuse herself from the conversation.
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [effect on Josephine Blackwood] It changes her plans for the evening because she excused herself from the conversation and will not be having dinner with the group.
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [effect on Millicent Cartwright] It changes the conversation she is currently having.
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] Silas Redburn bought a pint of ale and a plate of salted pork from the bartender, spending 50 cents and reducing his coin to 5.00.
